choices.text: Pain begins after few hours of onset of periods and can last up to 48 hours
It is dependent on psychological factors
Pain begins 3 days prior to the onset of periods and is present up to the second day of the period
GnRH antagonists are the first line of treatment

questions.text: Which of these statements regarding primary dysmenorrhea is true? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It Is dependent on psychological factors

 

Primary dysmenorrhea can be dependent on psychological factors.

 

Secondary dysmenorrhea is associated with the presence of pelvic pathologies.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pain begins after few hours of onset of periods and can last up to 48 hours and Option C. Pain begins 3 days prior to the onset of periods and is present up to the second day of the period: Pain begins before or with onset of menstrual periods.

 

Option D. GnRH antagonists are the first line of treatment: NSAIDs are the first line of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary dysmenorrhea, characterized by menstrual pain without underlying pelvic pathology, can be influenced by psychological factors. This type of dysmenorrhea begins before or with the onset of menstrual periods and is typically treated first with NSAIDs, not GnRH antagonists.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient undergoes a pacemaker replacement procedure at a tertiary care hospital. The surgeon successfully replaces the pacemaker and hands over the used device to the nursing staff for proper disposal as per biomedical waste management guidelines. According to the guidelines for biomedical waste management, in which colored bag should the used pacemaker be discarded? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Blue

 

  • According to biomedical waste management guidelines, used pacemakers, which are considered metal waste, should be disposed of in blue-colored containers or cardboard boxes marked with blue.
  • This ensures that the device is appropriately handled, disinfected, and sent for recycling or other safe disposal methods.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following set of values suggest primary hypothyroidism? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low T4; High TSH

 

Primary hypothyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland itself is not producing enough thyroid hormones (T4 and T3). This deficiency in thyroid hormone production leads to a decrease in circulating T4 levels. The pituitary gland responds to low T4 levels by increasing the secretion of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) in an attempt to stimulate the thyroid gland to produce more thyroid hormones.

 

Thus, in primary hypothyroidism, the typical laboratory findings are:

 

  • Low T4: Indicates underproduction of thyroid hormone by the thyroid gland.
  • High TSH: Indicates the pituitary gland's response to low thyroid hormone levels by secreting more TSH to stimulate the thyroid gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low T4; Low TSH: This pattern suggests secondary (or central) hypothyroidism, where the problem lies either in the pituitary gland (which produces TSH) or the hypothalamus (which produces TRH that stimulates TSH production). Both T4 and TSH are low because the pituitary gland is not secreting enough TSH to stimulate the thyroid gland.

 

Option C. High T4; High TSH: This pattern is indicative of central hyperthyroidism, where there is excessive production of TSH from the pituitary gland, leading to an overactive thyroid and high levels of T4.

 

Option D. High T4; Low TSH: This pattern suggests primary hyperthyroidism, where the thyroid gland is overactive and produces too much thyroid hormone, leading to high T4 levels. The pituitary gland responds by reducing TSH production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary hypothyroidism is characterized by low T4 levels and high TSH levels due to the thyroid gland's failure to produce sufficient thyroid hormones and the pituitary gland's compensatory increase in TSH secretion.

questions.text: In the accompanying illustration, a treatment approach for a patient with lymphatic filariasis is depicted. Which type of preventive method is illustrated in this scenario? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Disability limitation

 

  • The image shows an established case of chronic lymphatic filariasis, where hygiene is being maintained to prevent further disability by secondary bacterial infection.
  • Disability limitation is a mode of intervention in tertiary prevention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Specific protection: Health promotion is a mode of intervention in primary prevention, and is the process of enabling people to increase control over, and improve health. Health promotion may be achieved through health education, environmental modification, nutritional interventions or lifestyle changes.

 

Option C. Primary prevention: Primary prevention is a level of prevention which is defined as action taken prior to the onset of a disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. It is accomplished by measures designed to promote general health and well-being.

 

Option D. Health promotion: Specific protection is a mode of intervention in primary prevention which aims at limiting the number of cases of a particular disease. This includes immunization, use of specific nutrients, chemoprophylaxis, accident protection, and avoidance of allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disability limitation is a mode of tertiary prevention aimed at managing existing disease and preventing further complications, as illustrated in the treatment approach for a patient with chronic lymphatic filariasis in the image.

questions.text: Plasmodium species that commonly affects the brain:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Falciparum

 

Explanation

 

Plasmodium falciparum is known for its ability to cause severe malaria, including cerebral malaria, which affects the brain. This species can lead to complications such as seizures, coma, and other neurological symptoms due to its ability to adhere to the endothelium of blood vessels in the brain, causing blockage of blood flow and resulting in cerebral symptoms.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Vivax: Generally causes milder forms of malaria and is less likely to cause cerebral involvement.

 

Option C. Malaria: Known for chronic malaria but rarely causes cerebral symptoms.

 

Option D. Ovale: Typically associated with milder forms of malaria and does not commonly cause cerebral complications.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Plasmodium falciparum is the species most commonly associated with cerebral malaria, affecting the brain.

questions.text: The temperature of a body of a deceased person is found to be 39 degrees Celsius. Which of the following is the most probable reason? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Septicaemia

 

Septicaemia, a severe infection where bacteria enter the bloodstream, causes the body to produce a high fever due to excessive bacterial activity. This can result in postmortem caloricity, where the body temperature remains elevated after death.

 

Postmortem Caloricity: Usually cooling of the body occurs after death, however in certain exceptional conditions the body temperatures remain increased after death for 2-3 hours. This is called Postmortem Caloricity.

 

It can Occur due to two reasons:

 

1) Body temperature was too high before death

 

  1. When Heat regulation is disturbed before death: Heat Stroke, pontine hemorrhage    
  2. Increased heat production due to convulsions: Strychnine poisoning and tetanus
  3. Increased heat production due to excessive bacterial activity: Infectious diseases (Septicaemia, typhoid etc.)

 

2) Very high environmental temperature

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyanide poisoning: Cyanide poisoning leads to rapid death by inhibiting cellular respiration, but it does not typically cause elevated postmortem body temperature.

 

Option C. Corrosive poisoning: Corrosive poisons cause tissue damage and may lead to symptoms such as pain and vomiting, but they do not typically result in postmortem caloricity.

 

Option D. Intra-abdominal hemorrhage: Intra-abdominal hemorrhage involves bleeding within the abdominal cavity, which does not cause elevated postmortem body temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmortem caloricity, where the body temperature remains elevated after death, can occur due to high body temperature before death, such as in cases of septicaemia, heat stroke, and certain poisonings, or due to very high environmental temperature.

 

Ref: Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology, 5th edition, Krishan Vij, page 81

choices.text: Oral candidiasis is common with its use.
It has fewer side effects than other inhalational corticosteroids.
It is a prodrug activated by bronchial esterase.
It has comparable efficacy to other inhalational corticosteroids.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Ciclesonide is incorrect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis is common with its use.

 

Ciclesonide is an inhalational corticosteroid used to manage asthma and other respiratory conditions.

 

It is unique among inhaled corticosteroids because it is a "soft steroid" and functions as a prodrug. This means that Ciclesonide is inactive when administered and only becomes active when it reaches the lungs, where it is converted into its active form by bronchial esterases. This activation in the target site, the bronchial airways, significantly reduces the drug's systemic side effects, including the risk of oral candidiasis, which is common with other inhaled corticosteroids.

 

Because the majority of the drug that deposits in the oropharynx remains inactive, the likelihood of developing oral candidiasis (a common side effect of other inhalational steroids due to local immunosuppression) is significantly lower with Ciclesonide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It has fewer side effects than other inhalational corticosteroids: This statement is correct. Due to its activation in the bronchial tree, Ciclesonide has fewer systemic and local side effects compared to other inhalational corticosteroids.

 

Option C. It is a prodrug activated by bronchial esterase: This is also correct. Ciclesonide remains inactive until it reaches the lungs, where it is converted into its active form by bronchial esterases.

 

Option D. It has comparable efficacy to other inhalational corticosteroids: This is correct. Ciclesonide is just as effective as other inhalational corticosteroids in managing respiratory conditions such as asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ciclesonide, a prodrug inhalational corticosteroid, has a lower risk of causing oral candidiasis compared to other inhalational steroids because it remains inactive until it reaches the lungs, where it is activated by bronchial esterases.

questions.text: Which drug is contraindicated in a patient with atonic PPH with a history of hypertension? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ergotamine

 

Ergotamine (or methylergometrine) is an ergot alkaloid that is commonly used as a uterotonic agent to manage postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) by promoting uterine contractions. However, it has potent vasoconstrictive properties, which significantly increase vascular resistance and blood pressure.

 

In patients with a history of hypertension, the use of ergotamine is contraindicated because its vasoconstrictive effect can lead to a dangerous rise in blood pressure. This increase in afterload can put additional strain on the heart and may precipitate hypertensive crises or other cardiovascular complications. Therefore, ergotamine is avoided in hypertensive patients, particularly in those with chronic hypertension or other cardiovascular diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E1 analogue that is also used to manage postpartum hemorrhage. It induces uterine contractions but does not have significant vasoconstrictive effects. Therefore, it is not contraindicated in patients with hypertension.

 

Option B. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is another uterotonic agent that works by stimulating uterine contractions. While it can cause mild vasodilation, it does not have the strong vasoconstrictive properties of ergotamine and is generally safe to use in hypertensive patients.

 

Option D. PGF2 alpha: Certain prostaglandins can increase blood pressure and should be used with caution, but they are not as strongly contraindicated as ergotamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ergotamine is contraindicated in patients with hypertension due to its potent vasoconstrictive effects, which can significantly increase blood pressure and cause cardiovascular complications. This drug should be avoided in hypertensive patients, especially when managing postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 39-year-old patient presents to the OPD with the complaint of pain over his ear. He also complains of difficulty in eating food and the inability to close his eyes completely. On examination, there is a swelling below his ear. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved in this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Facial nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's symptoms, including ear pain, difficulty eating, and inability to close the eye completely, strongly suggest a case of facial palsy or Bell's palsy. Bell's palsy is a condition characterized by sudden weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles, typically affecting one side of the face. The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression, and its dysfunction leads to the presented symptoms.

 

The presence of a swelling below the ear further supports the involvement of the facial nerve. The parotid gland, located in this region, is closely associated with the facial nerve, which divides into five terminal branches within the gland. Damage or inflammation of the parotid gland can lead to compression or involvement of the facial nerve, resulting in facial palsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Great auricular nerve: Incorrect. While the great auricular nerve provides sensory innervation over the angle of the mandible and the area around the ear (shaving area), it is not directly responsible for the motor functions affected in this case. If the patient had ear pain or loss of sensation in the shaving area without the Bell's palsy features, the great auricular nerve could have been considered.

 

Option C. Vagus nerve: Incorrect. The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) does not directly control the facial muscles or cause the symptoms described here.

 

Option D. Auriculotemporal nerve: Incorrect. The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory innervation to the auricle and temporal region but does not control the facial muscles or cause the symptoms of facial palsy. If the patient had symptoms like increased sweating, redness, or blood supply in this area, it could have suggested an auriculotemporal nerve syndrome (Frey's syndrome).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression, and its dysfunction can lead to facial palsy or Bell's palsy, characterized by weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles, difficulty eating, and inability to close the eye completely.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning is? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dimercaprol

 

Dimercaprol is a traditional chelating agent of choice for acute arsenic poisoning. Though now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity. Amongst the given choices, dimercaprol is best answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ipecac: Ipecac is rapidly acting anti-emetic. Earlier it was sometimes used to remove different types of unabsorbed poisons in GIT, but now it is no longer recommended due to limited benefits

 

Option B. Penicillamine: Though it can be used in arsenic, but not a preferred agent. It is preferred chelator for copper.

 

Option C. Activated charcoal: Not useful as it does not adsorb arsenic and other heavy metals

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Acute Arsenic poisoning

 

  • Hemodynamic stabilization for significant GI losses (vomiting and diarrhea)
  • Gastric lavage is done repeatedly with large amount of warm water and milk;
  • Chelating Agents
    • Chelating agents are useful in acute arsenic poisoning, but have very limited role in chronic arsenic poisoning
    • There are three chelating agents useful in acute arsenic poisoning:
      1. British Anti Lewisite (BAL, aka dimercaprol, dimercaptopropanol): available in IM route. Traditionally BAL was used most commonly for As, but now DMSA and DMPS are considered better, as they can be given orally and have lower toxicity.
      2. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally
      3. Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV. DMPS is agent of choice for acute As poisoning.

choices.text: Antibiotic eye drops post surgery

questions.text: After cataract surgery, endophthalmitis developed. How will you prevent post operative endophthalmitis?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Povidone iodine before surgery 

 

The most widely accepted method for preventing postoperative endophthalmitis is  Povidone-Iodine Before Surgery. It is recognized as a crucial step in the preoperative preparation of cataract surgery to minimize the risk of infection.

 

Povidone-iodine is an effective antiseptic that is widely used to reduce the risk of postoperative endophthalmitis. Applying povidone-iodine to the ocular surface before surgery can significantly decrease the number of pathogenic organisms in the operative field, thereby reducing the risk of postoperative infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intravitreal Anti-bacterial Injections: Intravitreal antibiotics are used as a treatment for established endophthalmitis, not as a prophylactic measure. Giving these injections as a routine prevention measure is not standard due to the potential risks, such as retinal detachment or injection-related infections.

 

Option C. Mydriatics Before Surgery: Mydriatics are medications used to dilate the pupils. They are important for cataract surgery because they provide the surgeon with better visibility of the lens. However, they do not have an antimicrobial effect and therefore would not prevent endophthalmitis.

 

Option D. Antibiotic Eye Drops Post-Surgery: Antibiotic eye drops post-surgery are commonly prescribed as a prophylactic measure to reduce the risk of infection. While their efficacy in preventing endophthalmitis is debated, they are still widely used in the postoperative period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To prevent postoperative endophthalmitis following cataract surgery, the application of povidone-iodine on the ocular surface before surgery is the standard prophylactic procedure.

questions.text: A patient with alkaline urine has the presence of the following type of urinary crystals. What is the likely composition of these crystals?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Magnesium ammonium phosphate

 

The presence of urinary crystals can help diagnose the type of stones a patient may be forming. The type of crystal seen in the urine is highly dependent on the urine pH:

 

Magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite): These crystals are typically found in alkaline urine and have a characteristic "coffin lid" appearance. They are associated with infections by urease-producing bacteria and are also known as staghorn calculi due to their large, branching structure in the kidneys.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Calcium oxalate: These crystals are typically found in acidic to neutral urine and have an envelope or dumbbell shape. They are the most common type of kidney stones.

 

Option B. Uric acid: These crystals are found in acidic urine and often have a rosette or irregular shape.

 

Option C. Cystine: These crystals appear in acidic urine and have a hexagonal shape, associated with cystinuria, a genetic disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Magnesium ammonium phosphate crystals, which appear as "coffin lid" shapes, are typically found in alkaline urine and are associated with struvite stones.

 

Urinary Crystals and pH Association:

questions.text: Identify the article in the constitution that is not related to pediatrics? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 42

 

Article 42 says that the state shall make provision for securing just and humane conditions of work and maternity relief. It is not directly related to pediatrics but rather focuses on the welfare of workers and maternity benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Articles in constitution related to children:

 

Option A. Article 21 A: Right to free and compulsory elementary education in the 6 -14-year age group.

 

Option B. Article 24: Right to be protected from any hazardous employment till 14 years of age.

 

Option C. Article 39 E: Right to be protected from being abused.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Article 42 is not related to pediatrics, as it focuses on working conditions and maternity relief, unlike Articles 21A, 24, and 39E, which are specifically aimed at the rights and protection of children.

questions.text: What is occipitomental view also known as? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Waters view

 

Occipitomental view is also called Water's view.

 

Water's view: The patient's head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film while the X-rays are projected from backward.

 

Structures seen in Water's view are:

 

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone
  • Frontal process of maxilla
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Infratemporal fossa

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Towne's view - Typically used for imaging the skull, particularly the occipital bone and foramen magnum.

 

 

Structures seen  

Arcuate eminence

Superior semicircular canal

Mastoid antrum

Internal auditory canal

Tympanic cavity

Cochlea

External auditory canal

 

Clinical application Acoustic neuroma, Petrositis

 

Option C. Law's view - Generally related to imaging of the shoulder or elbow, not applicable here.

 

Option D. Stenver's view - A radiographic projection used primarily for detailed imaging of the mastoid process and middle ear structures.

Structures seen

Arcuate eminence

Internal auditory meatus

Labyrinth with vestibule

Mastoid antrum

Cochlea

Entire petrous pyramid

 

 

Educational Objective:


Water's view is crucial for diagnosing sinus-related pathologies, especially those affecting the maxillary and frontal sinuses. It is a fundamental technique in sinus imaging protocols, providing critical information for the diagnosis and management of sinus conditions.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493

choices.text: Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, HBV, Injectable Polio
Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Haemophilus influenza B, Pneumococcal vaccine
Diphtheria, Tetanus, HBV, Haemophilus influenza B, Pertussis

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic for her first round of vaccinations. The mother is anxious and wants to ensure her child receives all the necessary immunizations. You explain that one of the shots the child will receive is the Pentavalent vaccine, which combines five different immunizations into a single injection. Which of the following immunizations are combined in the Pentavalent vaccine? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Diphtheria, Tetanus, HBV, Haemophilus influenza B, Pertussis

 

  • Pentavalent vaccine consists of five vaccines - Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Hepatitis B and Haemophilus Influenzae Type B (Hib).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

questions.text: Identify the image shown below. (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gunshot wound

 

The given image is of a gunshot wound.

 

Features of gunshot wound:

 

  • Central round hole with surrounding soot soiling.

  • Burnt hairs (singeing).

  • Punctate skin lesions from powder particles (tattooing).

  • Bevelling of edges (Exit Wounds)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tattooing: While tattooing refers to punctate skin lesions caused by powder particles in gunshot wounds, it alone does not describe the entirety of the image shown.

 

Option C. Arsenic poisoning: Arsenic poisoning typically causes symptoms like skin changes, but not the characteristic central hole and surrounding soot seen in gunshot wounds.

 

Option D. Graze wound: A graze wound is typically a superficial wound caused by the bullet skimming the surface of the skin, which looks different from the wound shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A gunshot wound can be identified by its central round hole, surrounding soot, singeing of hairs, tattooing from powder particles, and bevelling of the wound edges.

choices.text: It is caused by staphylococcus only
It is a case of testicular torsion

questions.text: A 40-year-old Type 2 diabetic patient presents with fever and hypotension to the casualty. He gives a history of a boil in the perianal area which developed 2 weeks ago. On examination, the perianal area is as shown in the picture below. Identify the correct statement about this condition? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The testis remains unaffected

 

The patient's presentation, along with the examination findings, suggest Fournier's gangrene. This is a life-threatening necrotizing fasciitis of the perineal and genital regions requiring prompt medical and surgical intervention.

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is characterized by rapid progression and extensive tissue necrosis. It is a polymicrobial infection often involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria from gastrointestinal or genitourinary sources. Immediate treatment includes surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

 

The infection in Fournier's gangrene usually affects superficial tissues and skin but spares the testes due to their separate blood supply from the testicular artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is caused by staphylococcus only: Incorrect. While Staphylococcus species can be involved, Fournier's gangrene is typically polymicrobial, involving multiple bacteria such as E. coli, Klebsiella, and anaerobes, along with staphylococci.

 

Option C. It is a self-resolving condition: Incorrect. Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressing and severe condition that requires urgent surgical and medical treatment. Without intervention, it can lead to sepsis and be fatal.

 

Option D. It is a case of testicular torsion: Incorrect. Testicular torsion involves twisting of the spermatic cord, leading to acute severe scrotal pain and ischemia of the testis. This condition is different from Fournier's gangrene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fournier's gangrene is a severe necrotizing infection of the perineal and genital regions, often sparing deeper structures like the testes. Immediate surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics are critical for management.

choices.text: Point B is 3 cm lateral to point A
Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal
Point A receives a dose of 7000 cGy
Point B receives a dose of 6000 cGy

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman diagnosed with carcinoma cervix stage 2B was advised radiotherapy. Which of the following statements regarding radiotherapy is false? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal

 

Point A

 

  • A point 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os.
  • Represents the anatomical location of the ureter.
  • The total dose to point A should not exceed 8000 cGy.

 

Point B

 

  • A point 3 cm lateral to point A.
  • Represents a dose to the pelvic wall.
  • The dose to point B is about 25 30% of the dose to point A (4500 6500 cGy).

 

False Statement Explanation

 

  • Point A is 2 cm above the external os and 5 cm lateral to the internal uterine canal:
    • This statement is false because Point A is defined as 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os, not 5 cm lateral.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Point A in cervical cancer radiotherapy is located 2 cm lateral and 2 cm superior to the external cervical os, and the total dose should not exceed 8000 cGy.

 

Ref: Page no 350, DC Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is a water soluble contrast? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Iohexol

 

Explanation:

 

lohexol is a non-ionic, water-soluble iodinated contrast medium, used in various radiographic studies including CT scans, angiography, and myelography. It is known for its low osmolality and good safety profile, making it suitable for intravascular use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Barium: While barium sulfate is a contrast agent, it is not water-soluble and is primarily used for gastrointestinal studies.

 

Option C. Bromium: Not typically used as a contrast agent in medical imaging.

 

Option D. Calcium: Not used as a contrast agent. In medical imaging, calcium deposits may be identified by their radiographic appearance, but calcium itself is not administered as a contrast medium.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: No of live births per 1000 women in reproductive age group is?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) General fertility rate

 

Explanation:

 

The general fertility rate is defined as the total number of live births in a community in a year divided by the total number of women in the reproductive age group (usually 15-49 years) per 1,000.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total fertility rate (TFR): Incorrect. TFR refers to the total number of children born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan.

 

Option C. Age specific fertility rate (ASFR): Incorrect. Age-specific fertility rate is the fertility rate calculated for a given age interval, usually 5 years, per 1,000 mid-year population.

 

Option D. Gross reproduction rate: Incorrect. Gross reproduction rate (GRR) is the total number of girl children born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan at current ASFRs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The general fertility rate is the number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group (usually 15-49 years) in a given year.

 

Note - Net reproduction rate (NRR): Expected number of daughters, per newborn prospective mother, who may or may not survive to and through the ages of childbearing.

choices.text: Human papilloma virus
Herpes simplex virus
Human immunodeficiency virus

questions.text: Which of the following is the causative organism of vulval warts? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human papilloma virus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Benign vulval warts are caused by HPV-6 and 11 (low risk HPV types)

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Herpes simplex virus: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) causes genital herpes, characterized by painful vesicular lesions.

 

Option C. Human immunodeficiency virus: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) causes AIDS, which leads to immunosuppression and various opportunistic infections.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a member of the herpesvirus family and can cause infections in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not cause vulval warts.

 

Sexually Transmitted Infections

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Benign vulval warts (condyloma acuminata) are caused by HPV types 6 and 11.

 

Ref: Page no 146, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: True regarding mitochondrial genome?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maternal inheritance

 

  • The mitochondrial genome is inherited maternally, which means it is passed down from the mother to her offspring. This is because mitochondria are typically inherited from the cytoplasm of the egg cell. Sperm contributes very little, if any, mitochondria to the zygote, and paternal mitochondria are usually degraded after fertilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Low Rate of Mutation: False Mitochondrial DNA is known to have a relatively high mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA. This higher mutation rate is partly due to the lack of protective histones and efficient DNA repair mechanisms in mitochondria. As a result, mutations in mitochondrial DNA can accumulate over time.

 

Option C. Single-stranded DNA: False Mitochondrial DNA is double-stranded, just like nuclear DNA. It forms a circular double-stranded DNA molecule. This structure is distinct from the single-stranded DNA found in some viruses and certain cellular processes.

 

Option D. Paternal Inheritance: False Mitochondrial DNA is not inherited from the father; it is exclusively maternally inherited. Paternal mitochondria are generally not passed on to the offspring during fertilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial DNA and RNA:

 

  1. There is a dichotomy on the mitochondrial metabolism. Some of the mitochondrial protein synthesis is under the control of mitochondrial DNA; but important proteins of the outer membrane of the mitochondria are synthesized under the influence of nuclear DNA.
  2. The mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is circular, has about 16,500 nucleotides. The mtDNA has information for synthesis of 2 ribosomal RNAs, 22 tRNAs and 13 proteins. All of them are components of electron transport chain. It has 37 genes that encode 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain (total of 67 i.e., about 20%). However, most of mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA and synthesized in the cytoplasm.
  3. Maternal inheritance: Since, the mitochondria are inherited cytoplasmically, the mtDNA is inherited from the mother. Mother transmits mtDNA through oocyte.
  4. There are hundreds of copies of mtDNA in each cell (nuclear DNA has only 2 copies).
  5. Heteroplasmy is defined as the presence of normal and mutant mtDNA in different proportions in different cells. During cell division, mtDNA replicates and they segregate to the daughter cells. If a mutation occurs in mtDNA, the daughter cells may inherit the mutant or normal mtDNA.
  6. High mutation rate: 5-10 times that of nuclear DNA
  7. Age-related accumulation of mutations in mtDNA may be responsible for age-related decrease in cellular OXPHOS function, and progression of other degenerative diseases.
  8. Defects in mitochondrial genome will lead to mitochondrial myopathies.

questions.text: A patient addressing from Delhi presents with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm3, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm3, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dengue

 

The patient with given symptoms and lab results, points out to diagnosis of dengue fever.

 

Dengue, aka Break Bone Fever

 

 

Shown below is an image of the rash in dengue:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria patients presents with clinical features like periodic bouts of fever with chills and rigors, followed by anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.

 

Option C. Scrub typhus patients typically presents with a characteristic eschar, which is a punched-out ulcer covered with a blackened scab at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. Heres an image of the eschar.

 

 

Option D. Typhoid (enteric) fever presents with fever, abdominal pain, headache, chills, myalgia, malaise, diarrhea, sweating, nausea, and vomiting. Rose spots are classical, pink macules on the abdomen and the chest. Hepatosplenomegaly and relative bradycardia might be seen. The WBC count vary from normal to low.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of fever, arthralgia, petechial rash, and significant thrombocytopenia in a patient from an area where dengue is endemic should prompt immediate consideration of dengue fever, with prompt initiation of supportive care and monitoring for potential complications such as DHF or DSS.

questions.text: An individual undergoes a bone marrow examination which shows the presence of the cells as shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely enzyme defect associated with this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glucocerebrosidase

 

The presence of gaucher cells with a crumpled paper appearance is suggestive of Gauchers disease. It is caused by deficiency of glucocerebrosidase.

 

Gaucher's Disease:

 

  • Pathology: Gaucher's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glucocerebroside into glucose and ceramide.
  • Clinical Features: Patients may present with hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and bone pain or fractures.
  • Histopathology: Gaucher cells are macrophages filled with lipid-laden lysosomes. These cells have a characteristic crumpled paper appearance due to the accumulation of glucocerebroside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hexosaminidase: Deficiency causes Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by a cherry-red spot on the macula.

 

Option C. Alpha 1,4 glucosidase: Deficiency causes Pompe disease, characterized by glycogen accumulation in lysosomes.

 

Option D. Galactosidase: Deficiency causes Fabry disease, characterized by angiokeratomas, acroparesthesia, and renal failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gaucher cells with a crumpled paper appearance in a bone marrow examination are indicative of Gaucher's disease, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

 

Gaucher Disease Overview:

questions.text: The recommended temperature of water bath for a patient with frost bite is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 37 degrees C

 

Frostbite should be managed with rapid and complete thawing using a circulating water bath maintained between 37C and 40C. This temperature range is optimal to reverse vascular stasis and initiate reperfusion without causing thermal injury.

 

Thawing at this range is typically performed for 30 to 60 minutes and should be done only when the possibility of refreezing is excluded. Higher temperatures like 42C are not recommended and may worsen tissue injury.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. 42C: Too hot. It exceeds the upper recommended limit and can risk thermal damage to already compromised tissue.

 

Option C. 32C: Insufficient to produce effective rewarming. Rewarming would be slow and incomplete.

 

Option D. 30C: Ineffective. Tissue remains partially frozen and vulnerable to re-freezing injury.

 

Educational Objective:


Frostbite should be rewarmed in circulating water at 3740C for 3060 minutes, avoiding hot air or dry heat.

choices.text: Focal area of decreased air entry will be suggestive of foreign body
In complete obstruction, ball and valve mechanism causes hyperinflation
The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis

questions.text: A previously healthy child presented with acute-onset dyspnea. A chest X-ray shows unilateral hyperinflation of the lungs. What is true for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Focal area of decreased air entry will be suggestive of foreign body

 

The clinical presentation suggests the presence of a foreign body in the airway, most likely in the bronchi, causing incomplete airway obstruction. This would be evident on auscultation as a focal area of decreased air entry. This condition is more common in children under 4 years old, and food items are the most common foreign bodies. Non-irritating types, such as plastic, glass, or metallic foreign bodies, and irritating types, such as vegetables, peanuts, beans, and seeds, are frequently encountered. The right bronchus is more susceptible to foreign body impaction because it is wider and more in line with the tracheal lumen.

 

Evaluation:

 

  • A plain X-ray chest in posteroanterior and lateral views (expiratory films are useful) is performed to evaluate a foreign body in the airway.
  • The X-ray may show the radio-opaque foreign body's size, shape, and location, lobar or segmental atelectasis in complete airway obstruction, or hyperinflation or obstructive emphysema of the affected area due to the ball valve mechanism.

 

Management:

 

  • The management of foreign body airway depends on the location of the foreign body.
  • A laryngeal foreign body can be treated with the Heimlich maneuver, and if it fails, cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy should be performed.
  • Foreign bodies in the trachea and bronchi can be removed using a rigid bronchoscope after adequate hydration and emptying of the stomach.
  • Appropriate antibiotics are given to prevent secondary infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flexible bronchoscopy used for removal: Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred over flexible bronchoscopy for the removal of foreign bodies in the trachea and bronchi because it allows better visualization and manipulation.

 

Option C. In complete obstruction, ball and valve mechanism causes hyperinflation: Incomplete obstruction, not complete obstruction, is associated with the ball valve mechanism, which causes hyperinflation by allowing air to enter but not leave the affected area.

 

Option D. The child has developed acute laryngotracheobronchitis: Laryngotracheobronchitis, or croup, is caused by the parainfluenza virus. It commonly affects children aged 6 months to 3 years and presents with a barking cough, biphasic stridor, and low-grade fever. The chest X-ray shows a narrowing of the subglottic region known as the steeple sign, which is not consistent with the presented case of foreign body aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of acute-onset dyspnea with unilateral hyperinflation on chest X-ray, a focal area of decreased air entry is suggestive of foreign body aspiration, which is more common in children under 4 years old.

questions.text: A patient has multiple tendon xanthomas. Serum cholesterol (398 mg/dL) and LDL 220 mg/dL were found to be raised. What is the defect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LDL receptors defect

 

The patient's symptoms of multiple tendon xanthomas, elevated serum cholesterol, and high LDL levels indicate Type II hyperlipoproteinemia, commonly known as familial hypercholesterolemia. This condition is primarily caused by a defect in LDL receptors, leading to impaired clearance of LDL from the bloodstream. The resulting elevated LDL levels promote cholesterol deposition in tendons, forming xanthomas. Treatment typically focuses on reducing LDL cholesterol levels through diet, medication, or in severe cases, LDL apheresis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoprotein lipase deficiency: This defect leads to Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, characterized by high levels of chylomicrons and triglycerides, but not elevated LDL or cholesterol. Symptoms typically include pancreatitis and eruptive xanthomas, not tendon xanthomas.

 

Option C. Apo E defect: Apo E defect leads to Type III hyperlipoproteinemia, also known as dysbetalipoproteinemia. This condition is associated with elevated remnants of chylomicrons and VLDL, resulting in palmar xanthomas, not tendon xanthomas, and does not specifically cause the high LDL levels seen in this patient.

 

Option D. LCAT deficiency: LCAT deficiency affects HDL cholesterol conversion to cholesterol esters and does not directly affect LDL levels. It is associated with conditions such as Norum disease or fish eye disease, presenting with corneal opacity and hemolytic anemia rather than tendon xanthomas or elevated LDL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LDL receptor defects cause familial hypercholesterolemia, characterized by elevated LDL, cholesterol levels, and tendon xanthomas.

questions.text: Identify the marked ligament?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PCL

 

In the image, the arrow points to a structure consistent with the location and orientation of the PCL. The PCL  attaches to the posterior tibial condyle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ACL (Anterior Cruciate Ligament): The ACL, crosses in the middle of the knee with the PCL but is positioned anteriorly on the tibia.

 

Option C. Meniscus: They are located throughout the articular surface of knee joint

 

Educational Objective :

 

The marked ligament in the MRI scan is the PCL (Posterior Cruciate Ligament). This identification is supported by the ligament's location and trajectory as depicted in the image.

questions.text: A 30-year-old drug addict presents to the emergency department with signs of unknown drug poisoning. The patient exhibits dilated pupils, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and tremors. On examination, the blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, and the heart rate is 120 beats per minute. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine intoxication

 

The patients symptomsdilated pupils, diaphoresis (sweating), tachycardia (elevated heart rate), hypertension (elevated blood pressure), and tremorsare indicative of increased sympathetic nervous system activity.

 

Cocaine is a powerful stimulant that inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin in the central nervous system. This leads to an accumulation of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft, which results in the heightened sympathetic activity seen in the patient, such as increased heart rate, blood pressure, and dilated pupils. Additionally, cocaine use can cause hyperthermia and diaphoresis, further supporting the diagnosis of cocaine intoxication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dhatura poisoning: While Dhatura poisoning can cause dilated pupils and tachycardia, it is also associated with anticholinergic effects like dry mouth, dry skin, and urinary retention. The presence of diaphoresis and tremors makes Dhatura poisoning less likely because Dhatura poisoning typically presents with decreased sweating (anhidrosis) rather than increased sweating.

 

Option C. Cannabis poisoning: Cannabis typically causes symptoms like euphoria, dry mouth, conjunctival injection (red eyes), and sometimes mild tachycardia. It does not usually cause the severe sympathetic overactivity described in this case, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option D. Alcohol intoxication: Acute alcohol intoxication generally causes central nervous system depression rather than stimulation. Symptoms may include slurred speech, impaired coordination, and in severe cases, respiratory depression. Alcohol does not cause the significant sympathetic stimulation seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine intoxication should be suspected in patients presenting with symptoms of increased sympathetic activity, such as dilated pupils, diaphoresis, tachycardia, hypertension, and tremors. Cocaine acts as a potent stimulant by inhibiting the reuptake of norepinephrine, leading to these clinical signs.

choices.text: Dark areas represent necrosis, white areas represent viable liver tissue
Dark areas represent viable liver tissue, white areas represent necrosis
White areas represent central hepatocytes

questions.text: A patient with cirrhosis and ascites presented to you. The gross appearance of his liver is as shown below. Which among the following is true about it? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark areas represent necrosis; white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

The above picture shows centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis. The cut liver section, in which major blood vessels are visible, is notable for a variegated, mottled, red appearance (nutmeg liver) seen in right heart failure. The dark areas represent necrosis; white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

Nutmeg liver refers to the mottled appearance of the liver which resembles the cut section of nutmeg. This occurs as a result of hepatic venous congestion following right heart failure. The dark centrilobular zones reflect sinusoidal congestion. Congestion is seen around the central veins usually from right-sided heart failure. The pale periportal zones reflect normal or fatty liver tissue.

 

The liver derives its blood supply from the portal venous system and the hepatic artery. The portal triad constitutes:

 

  • Branches of the hepatic artery
  • Portal vein
  • Bile duct

 

The blood from the portal vein and the hepatic artery flow through the intervening sinusoids and drains into the central vein. The central veins from adjacent lobules form interlobular veins, which then unite as hepatic veins and finally drain into the inferior vena cava.

 

The hepatic lobule is divided into three zones:

 

  • Zone 1 is the periportal area
  • Zone 2 is the Intermediate zone
  • Zone 3 is the area closest to the central vein

 

Right-sided cardiac failure leads to passive congestion of the liver. Left-sided cardiac failure leads to hypoperfusion and hypoxia of hepatocytes around central veins. The combination of hypoperfusion and retrograde congestion causes centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis, leading to this mottled appearance of the liver, known as nutmeg liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark areas represent viable liver tissue, white areas represent necrosis: This is incorrect because the dark areas are where necrosis has occurred due to congestion, not viable tissue.

 

Option C. White areas represent central hepatocytes: The white areas represent periportal zones, which are generally healthier and not central hepatocytes.

 

Option D. Dark areas represent peri-portal hepatocytes: The dark areas actually represent the centrilobular regions where necrosis has occurred, not the periportal hepatocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nutmeg liver is characterized by a mottled appearance, where dark areas represent necrosis due to chronic passive congestion, and white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1665

choices.text: Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved
Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved
Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected

questions.text: What is correct regarding the diagnosis based on the given image?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved

 

The above image shows confluent, red, pustular lesions in a single dermatome suggestive of herpes zoster or shingles. The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia (NOT Anterior nerve roots) for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • Thoracic dermatome is most commonly affected (NOT Trigeminal).
  • The rash is restricted to a dermatome, but sometimes a few chickenpoxtype lesions can be found elsewhere. The lesions are infectious
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  1. Painful zoster infections in adults
  2. Facial zoster at any age
  3. Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved: False. In herpes zoster, it is the dorsal (posterior) nerve roots and ganglia that are predominantly involved, not the anterior nerve roots. The virus remains latent in the dorsal root ganglia and reactivates there, leading to symptoms in the corresponding dermatomal distribution.

 

Option C. The lesions are not infectious: False. The lesions of herpes zoster are highly infectious, particularly when the blisters are open and the fluid is accessible. The virus contained in these lesions can infect individuals who have not previously had chickenpox or the vaccine, leading to varicella (chickenpox).

 

Option D. Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected: False. While the trigeminal dermatome can be significantly affected (especially concerning due to the risk of herpes zoster ophthalmicus if the ophthalmic branch is involved), it is not the most commonly affected dermatome. The thoracic dermatomes are more frequently involved in herpes zoster cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes zoster, commonly involves reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus within the dorsal root ganglion, leading to painful cutaneous eruptions that can affect mucous membranes within the involved dermatomes.
  • Herpes zoster lesions are infectious, particularly to those who are not immune to varicella-zoster virus, and thoracic dermatome is the most frequently affected area.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

choices.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate Decarboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase
E1: Pyruvate carboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

questions.text: This multienzyme complex converts Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA. Identify E1 and E2: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

 

Explanation:

 

The provided images depict the components and functioning of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, a key multienzyme complex in the metabolic pathway that converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA, an essential step linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle. This complex requires vitamins B1, B2, B3, B5, and lipoic acid as cofactors.

 

Table: Components of PDH complex and their roles

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyruvate Decarboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as Pyruvate Decarboxylase is not involved in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in this context, and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase is the E3 component of the complex.

 

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase: Incorrect because Pyruvate carboxylase is involved in a different metabolic pathway (gluconeogenesis), not in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.

 

Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as the second enzyme is E3 in this complex, not E2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 162

questions.text: In a RTA (road traffic accident), a person suffered from injury to the bulbar urethra. What can be the location of the collection of the urine due to this injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior abdominal wall

 

Explanation:

 

Injury to the bulbar urethra, such as from a road traffic accident, can lead to the collection of urine in the anterior abdominal wall. The bulbar urethra is part of the spongy urethra and is located in the perineal region. When this part of the urethra ruptures, urine extravasates into the surrounding tissues.

 

The typical path of urine extravasation due to a bulbar urethral injury includes:

 

  1. Perineum: Initially, urine accumulates around the scrotum and the perineum.
  2. Superficial perineal pouch: Urine then spreads into the superficial perineal pouch.
  3. Anterior abdominal wall: From the superficial perineal pouch, urine can extend into the anterior abdominal wall, following the fascial planes.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Deep perineal pouch: Rupture of the membranous urethra would lead to urine collection in the deep perineal pouch, not typically the case with bulbar urethral injury.

 

Option  B. Peritoneal cavity: Urine does not usually enter the peritoneal cavity from a bulbar urethral injury.

 

Option D.  Ischiorectal fossa: This area is more likely affected in cases involving deep perineal infections or abscesses rather than bulbar urethral injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of bulbar urethral injury, urine typically accumulates in the perineum and can extend into the anterior abdominal wall but not into the deep perineal pouch or the peritoneal cavity.

choices.text: Ad Type of tympanogram is obtained
Notch at 2000Hz is indicative of Noise Induced hearing loss
Associated Mnire's disease is not a contraindication for stapes surgery
Air travelling is a contraindication for surgery

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant patient presented with complaints of worsening of hearing since the onset of pregnancy. On PTA the following graph was obtained. Which of the following statements regarding the disease is true? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Air travelling is a contraindication for surgery

 

Explanation:

 

The patient, being pregnant and experiencing worsening hearing loss, suggests otosclerosis. The provided PTA (Pure Tone Audiogram) shows a significant air-bone gap on the right side, indicating conductive hearing loss, which is consistent with otosclerosis.

 

Definitely, air travel is contraindicated for patients post-stapedectomy for at least three months. The variations in middle ear pressure during ascent and descent can lead to displacement or dislocation of the prosthetic piston used in the surgery, making this statement true.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ad Type of tympanogram is obtained: In otosclerosis, an As type of tympanogram (indicating reduced compliance of the middle ear system) is typically obtained, not Ad. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.

 

Option B. Notch at 2000Hz is indicative of Noise Induced hearing loss: A notch at 2000Hz on bone conduction is known as Carhart's notch, which is indicative of otosclerosis, not noise-induced hearing loss. Noise-induced hearing loss typically presents a notch at 4000Hz. Hence, this statement is incorrect.

 

Option C. Associated Mnire's disease is not a contraindication for stapes surgery: Mnire's disease is indeed a contraindication for stapes surgery. The presence of Mnire's disease can lead to complications such as irritation of the saccule during the surgery, causing vertigo and giddiness. Thus, this statement is false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Air travel is contraindicated for at least three months post-stapedectomy due to the risk of pressure-induced displacement or dislocation of the surgical prosthesis.

choices.text: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia
Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia
Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
Acute Myeloid Leukemia

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is being evaluated for leukemia. On investigation, WBC count was 4,50,000 /µL with eosinophilia and basophilia. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia  

 

A WBC count of 4,50,000/µL with eosinophilia and basophilia indicates a probable diagnosis of Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia: Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia presents with pancytopenia

 

Option C. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia shows smudge cells and small round lymphocytes in peripheral smear.

 

Option D. Acute Myeloid Leukemia: Acute Myeloid Leukemia shows myeloblasts with Auer rods. Clinically, patients have pancytopenia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia is characterized by extreme leukocytosis with eosinophilia and basophilia, and it is associated with the Philadelphia chromosome and the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

choices.text: Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the ER after falling off a horse. Her vitals are stable, but she complains of pain and tenderness in her lower abdomen and has not passed urine yet. On examination, there is a visible bruise over her lower abdomen, and blood is seen at the urethral meatus. The bladder is not palpable. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

 

The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible bladder injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy.

 

Trauma to lower abdomen with blood at urethral meatus implies urethral rupture. The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible urethral injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and then do a suprapubic cystostomy.

 

After bladder fills up with urine, a suprapubic cystostomy is done in immediate management of urethral rupture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and send her home: This option is not appropriate for a patient with a possible urethral injury.

 

Option B. Immediate insertion of Foley catheter: This option involves the insertion of a small tube through the urethra and into the bladder to drain urine. This is contraindicated in suspected urethral rupture, as it may create false passage.

 

Option C. Suprapubic aspiration of urine: This option involves inserting a needle through the skin and into the bladder to aspirate urine. This option may be preferred in cases where the urethra is injured or obstructed, making the insertion of a Foley catheter difficult. For this to be done, the bladder should be distended.

choices.text: Injury to base of skull - CSF Otorrhea
Penetrating trauma to eye - Battle sign

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match out of the following: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penetrating trauma to eye - Battle sign

 

  • The Battle sign is indicative of a base of skull fracture and not a result of penetrating trauma to the eye.

 

Battle sign refers to bruising that appears over the mastoid bone (located just behind the ear). It is a classic sign of a base of skull fracture, particularly in the posterior cranial fossa. Penetrating trauma to the eye does not produce a Battle sign. Therefore, this statement is incorrect, making it the right answer to the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EDH - ipsilateral pupil dilatation: EDH stands for Extradural Hemorrhage, which occurs when blood accumulates between the dura mater and the skull. This can lead to an increase in intracranial pressure, which may compress the third cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) on the same side of the injury, leading to ipsilateral (same side) pupil dilation. This statement is correct.

 

Option B. Injury to base of skull - CSF Otorrhea: CSF Otorrhea refers to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the ear. This can occur when there's a fracture in the base of the skull, which damages the barrier between the subarachnoid space (where CSF is present) and the inner ear, leading to CSF leakage. This statement is correct.

 

Option D. Midbrain injury gaze paresis: The midbrain, part of the brainstem, is involved in many functions, including the control of eye movements. Damage or injury to the midbrain can affect the cranial nerves responsible for eye movement, leading to gaze paresis, which is an inability or restriction in moving the eyes in certain directions. This statement is correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Battle sign is a classic indicator of a base of skull fracture and not associated with penetrating trauma to the eye.

questions.text: A portion of animals intestine is fixed in the Dales chamber. After infusing a drug, changes are seen in intestinal contractility as depicted in the graph. Which of the following agent resembles the effect? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adrenaline

 

Explanation:

 

The graph shows a decrease in the amplitude of intestinal contractions following the infusion of a drug. This decrease in contractility is indicative of the sympathetic nervous system's effect on the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. Adrenaline, a sympathetic agent, reduces GI motility and contractility, prioritizing the body's resources for a "fight or flight" response rather than digestion.

 

  • Adrenaline (epinephrine) activates the sympathetic nervous system. During stress, adrenaline reduces GI motility by decreasing the contractility of intestinal muscles, which is evident from the decreased amplitude in the graph.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetylcholine: Acetylcholine is associated with the parasympathetic nervous system, which enhances GI motility and contractility. Therefore, acetylcholine would increase, not decrease, the amplitude of intestinal contractions.

 

Option C. BaCl (Barium Chloride): Barium chloride increases the contractility of smooth muscles, often used in medical imaging to enhance the visibility of the GI tract. The increased contractility would result in an increased amplitude of contractions.

 

Option D. Serotonin: Serotonin increases GI motility and contractility. It plays a significant role in peristalsis by contracting the proximal part of the intestine. Thus, it would also increase the amplitude of contractions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenaline reduces the contractility of intestinal muscles by activating the sympathetic nervous system, resulting in decreased GI motility.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with pruritic eczematous rash on the neck and dorsum of hands. What is the likely nutritional deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B3

 

Explanation

 

Chronic alcoholics are prone to multiple nutrient deficiencies due to malnourishment and malnutrition. The given history is compatible with a disease called Pellagra, which is due to Niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency. Pellagra is characterized by the "3 D's": Diarrhea, Dermatitis, and Dementia, and it can also lead to death, sometimes referred to as the "4 D's."

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Vitamin B1: Causes Wernicke's encephalopathy, peripheral neuropathy, and heart failure but does not match the described skin condition.

 

Option C. Vitamin D: Associated with rickets and osteomalacia, not pruritic eczematous rash.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Causes scurvy with gum bleeding and other symptoms, not the described dermatitis.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Pellagra, characterized by the "3 D's" (Diarrhea, Dermatitis, Dementia), is caused by Vitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency and is commonly seen in chronic alcoholics.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used as an anti-smoking agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Varenicline

 

Varenicline is an FDA-approved medication that helps individuals quit smoking by reducing the craving and withdrawal symptoms associated with tobacco use. It acts as a partial agonist at alpha4 beta2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, which can both stimulate the receptor (to reduce craving) and block nicotine from binding (to reduce the rewarding effects of cigarettes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Busulfan: An alkylating agent used primarily in the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia.

 

Option B. Acamprosate: Used to treat alcohol dependence by reducing the craving for alcohol.

 

Option D. Gabapentin: An anticonvulsant that is also used for neuropathic pain and certain mood disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Varenicline is a partial agonist at 42 & 7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. As a partial agonist it prevents high and reinforcement and also controls craving and withdrawal due to tobacco use. It is the most effective agent for tobacco use disorders.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 505.
